sen.j: 及川氏（おいかわし）は、日本の氏族。

sen.j: 清和源氏（摂津源氏）源頼綱流。

sen.j: 及川の「及」は「およぶ」ではなく「笈」の異体字（または略字）。
sen.e: "及" of OIKAWA is not "およぶ," but a variation of "笈" (or the abbreviation).
The "及" of OIKAWA is not "およぶ" but instead a variation of "笈" (or an abbreviation).

sen.j: 全国人口順位282位、現在の日本では約2万軒、人口7万8400人。
sen.e: The ranking of population nationwide is the fifth place, currently in Japan there are about twenty thousand households and the number of population is seventy-eight thousand and four hundred.
It occupies in fifth place in the nationwide population ranking; currently in Japan there are about 20,000 households, representing a total of seventy-eight thousand four hundred individuals.

tit.e: The similarity of the family name

sen.j: 「及川・笈川」（おひかは）に似た姓としては、追川氏・生川氏があり、これらは当て字の違いにすぎず同系なのか、あるいはまったく別の姓なのか詳細不明である。
sen.e: As the names which are similar to "及川 and 笈川" (OHIKAWA), there are 追川氏 and 生川氏, but it is not well known that they are just phonetic equivalents and related or totally different names.

sen.j: また老川氏・翁川氏（おいかは）、小井川氏（をゐかは）等の苗字も存在するがこれらは別の姓であろう。
sen.e: And there also exist 老川氏, 翁川氏 (OIKAWA, おいかは) and 小井川氏 (OIKAWA, をゐかは), but they seem to be different names.

sen.j: 源頼政（馬場頼政）は『平家物語』の登場する有名な武将で歌人、鵺退治の伝説でも名高い。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yorimasa (Yorimasa BABA) was a famous samurai warrior and a poet who appears in "Heike Monogatari" (The tale of the Heike) and is renowned for getting rid of nue (Japanese legendary creature).

MINAMOTO no Yorimasa (Yorimasa BABA) was a famous samurai warrior and poet who appears in "Heike Monogatari (The Tale of the Heike)" and is renowned for getting rid of the nue (a creature of Japanese legend).

sen.j: その子・源仲綱から出た系統と、仲綱の異母弟・及川政嗣から出た系統とがある。
sen.e: There are the blood line from his son, MINAMOTO no Nakatsuna and the one from Nakatsuna's half brother, Masatsugu OIKAWA.
There is the bloodline from his son, MINAMOTO no Nakatsuna, as well as one from Nakatsuna's half-brother, Masatsugu OIKAWA.
There is the bloodline from his son, MINAMOTO no Nakatsuna, as well as one from Nakatsuna's younger paternal half-brother, Masatsugu OIKAWA.

sen.j: 仲綱の子・源成綱はのちに但馬国城崎郡（今の豊岡市近辺）の及川荘を領し、源成綱と称した。
sen.e: Later Nakatsuna's son, MINAMOTO no Naritsuna governed OIKAWA manor in Tajima Province Kinosaki County (currently near Toyooka city) and identified himself as MINAMOTO no Naritsuna.
Later, Nakatsuna's son MINAMOTO no Naritsuna governed OIKAWA manor in Tajima Province, Kinosaki County (near what is now Toyooka City) and identified himself as MINAMOTO no Naritsuna.
Later, Nakatsuna's son MINAMOTO no Naritsuna governed OIKAWA manor in Tajima Province, Kinosaki County (near what is now Toyooka City) and identified himself as MINAMOTO no Naritsuna.

sen.j: これによって始めて「及川」という名字が起こった。
sen.e: This firstly brought about the family name "OIKAWA."
This brought about the "OIKAWA" family name.
This brought about the 'OIKAWA' family name.

sen.j: 成綱（＝盛綱）の叔父・政嗣も成綱に従って及川を称し、この政嗣の系統が先に奥州において栄えたがのちに滅亡し、以後は成綱の系統がこれに代わって栄えた。
sen.e: Naritsuna (=Moritsuna)'s uncle, Masatsugu identified himself as OIKAWA, following Naritsuna and the Masatsugu blood line flourished in advance in Oshu, but later went to ruin and after that Naritsuna blood line flourished instead of this.

Naritsuna (Moritsuna)'s uncle, Masatsugu, identified himself as OIKAWA, whereupon Naritsuna and the Masatsugu bloodline flourished in Oshu, but later it went to ruin and consequently the Naritsuna bloodline flourished instead of this.

Naritsuna (Moritsuna)'s uncle, Masatsugu, identified himself as OIKAWA, whereupon Naritsuna and the Masatsugu bloodline flourished in Oshu, but later it went to ruin and consequently the Naritsuna bloodline flourished instead of this.

sen.j: 政嗣は、父・頼政が奥州に下向した時に残した胤で、一族中では奥州土着の先駆けとなった。
sen.e: Masatsugu was a descendant whom his father Yorimasa left when he went to Oshu leaving the capital, and among the families he became a frontier of localization in Oshu.
Masatsugu was a descendant whom his father Yorimasa left when he went to Oshu, leaving the capital, and among the families he became a pioneer of localization in Oshu.

sen.j: 政嗣は異母兄・仲綱より40歳以上も若く、おそらく甥の成綱よりも歳下であった。
sen.e: Masatsugu was 40 years younger than his older paternal half-brother Nakatsuna and was probably younger than his cousin Naritsuna.
Masatsugu was 40 years younger than his older paternal half-brother Nakatsuna and was probably younger than his cousin Naritsuna.
Masatsugu was probably more than 40 years younger than his older paternal half-brother Nakatsuna and was probably younger than his cousin Naritsuna.
sen.cmt: probably more thanを挿入しました。

sen.j: 政嗣が及川氏を称したのは同族として成綱に従ったことを示す。
sen.e: Masatsugu identified himself as OIKAWA clan, which means that he followed Naritsuna as his same family.
Masatsugu identified himself as being of the OIKAWA clan, meaning that he followed Naritsuna as part of the same family.
Masatsugu identified himself as being of the OIKAWA clan, meaning that he followed Naritsuna as part of the same family.

sen.j: 成綱の兄・源有綱は源頼朝の挙兵の際に参陣していることから、成綱もまた鎌倉幕府に従ったと思われる（神奈川県厚木市の「及川村」という地名は成綱または成綱の子・及川光綱の縁かとも思われるが、古くは「及河」とも書き「おいがわ」と濁って読むのが正しい。
sen.e: Naritsuna also seems to have followed Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) because Naritsuna's elder brother MINAMOTO no Aritsuna joined MINAMOTO no Yoritomo when Yoritomo rose up in arms (the place-name "OIGAWA village" in Atsugi city, Kanagawa prefecture seems to have a relation with Naritsuna or Naritsuna's son Mitsutsuna OIKAWA, but formerly it was also written as "及河" and correctly read as "OIGAWA" in a dull sound.

Apparetly, Naritsuna also followed the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) because Naritsuna's elder brother, MINAMOTO no Aritsuna, joined MINAMOTO no Yoritomo when Yoritomo rose up in arms (the place name "OIGAWA village" in Atsugi City, Kanagawa Prefecture, seems to have had a relationship with Naritsuna or Naritsuna's son Mitsutsuna OIKAWA, but formerly it was also written as "及河" and was properly read as "OIGAWA" in a dull sound.

Apparently, Naritsuna also followed the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) because Naritsuna's elder brother, MINAMOTO no Aritsuna, joined MINAMOTO no Yoritomo when Yoritomo rose up in arms (the place name 'OIGAWA village' in Atsugi City, Kanagawa Prefecture, seems to have had a relationship with Naritsuna or Naritsuna's son Mitsutsuna OIKAWA, but formerly it was also written as '及河' and was properly read as 'OIGAWA' in a dull sound.

sen.j: 現在、全及川氏の7％が神奈川県民）。
sen.e: At present, 7％ of all OIKAWA clan are residents of Kanagawa prefecture.
Today, seven percent of all OIKAWA clan members are residents of Kanagawa Prefecture.
Today, seven percent of all OIKAWA clan members are residents of Kanagawa Prefecture.

sen.j: 光綱の子孫・及川光重は、下総国の結城氏の家臣となって下総に土着、その子孫・及川光房は白河結城氏の家臣となり奥州（福島県）にも所領を得た（喜多方市に「笈川村」という地名あり、あるいはこの頃の及川氏に関係あるやにも思われるが、この地名ができたのは承応年間以後のことでそれ以前は新国（にっくに）といった）。
sen.e: Mitsutsuna's offspring Mitsushige OIKAWA became a retainer of Yuki clan in Shimousa Province and was localized in Shimousa and Mitsushige's offspring Mitsufusa OIKAWA became a retainer of Shirakawa Yuki clan and got a territory in Oshu (Fukushima prefecture) (there is the place-name "Oikawa village" in Kitakata city, which may suggest the relation with Oikawa clan in those days, but the birth of the place-name was after Shoo era and before that it was called Nikkuni).

Mitsutsuna's offspring Mitsushige OIKAWA became a retainer of the Yuki clan in Shimousa Province and was localized in Shimousa, and Mitsushige's offspring Mitsufusa OIKAWA became a retainer of the Shirakawa Yuki clan and obtained territory in Oshu (Fukushima Prefecture) (there is the place name "Oikawa village" in Kitakata City, which may suggest that there was a relationship with the Oikawa clan in those days, but the birth of the place name was after the Shoo era and previously it was called Nikkuni).

sen.j: 及川氏は岩手県南部から宮城県北部にかけて勢力を有した葛西氏の家臣となったが、その経緯から三つの家系に分かれている。
sen.e: OIKAWA clan became a retainer of KASAI clan who had influence from the south part of Iwate prefecture to the north part of Miyagi prefecture, but was divided into three family lines due to the developments.

The OIKAWA clan became a retainer of the KASAI clan, which had influence from the southern part of Iwate Prefecture to the north part of Miyagi Prefecture but, due to the consequent development, was divided into three family lines.

sen.j: 定嗣系
sen.e: Sadatsugu family line.

sen.j: まず政嗣の孫・及川定嗣がもっとも早期に葛西氏の家臣となっているが下に述べるようにのちに滅ぼされた。
sen.e: At first Masatsugu's grandson Sadatsugu OIKAWA became a retainer of KASAI clan in the earliest time, but he was exterminated because of the following reasons.

sen.e: Yoritada family line.

sen.j: 次いで、光綱の子孫にも、葛西家臣となり奥州に移住した者として及川頼只がいた。
sen.e: Next, there was Yoritada OIKAWA who became a KASAI's retainer and moved to Oshu in Mitsutsuna's offsprings.
Next, there was Yoritada OIKAWA, who became a retainer of the KASAI and moved to Oshu as one of Mitsutsuna's offspring.
Next, there was Yoritada OIKAWA, who became a retainer of the KASAI and moved to Oshu as one of Mitsutsuna's offspring.

sen.j: 光村系
sen.e: Mitsumura family line.
The Mitsumura family line
The Mitsumura family line

sen.j: 最後に葛西氏家臣となった系統である。
sen.e: It was the family line who became a KASAI's retainer at the end.
This was the family line that became a retainer of the KASAI at the end.
This was the family line that became a retainer of the KASAI at the end.

sen.j: 及川光房の曾孫・及川光政は結城合戦で討死、結城氏は一時滅亡となり、光政の子・及川光村はすべての所領を失い、逃げて葛西氏を頼った。
sen.e: Mitsufusa OIKAWA's great-grandson Mitsumura OIKAWA was killed in Yuki War and temporarily went to ruin and Mitsumasa's son Mitsumura OIKAWA lost his territories and ran away and sought refuge in KASAI clan.

Mitsufusa OIKAWA's great-grandson Mitsumura OIKAWA was killed in the Yuki War, so that the line temporarily went to ruin; Mitsumasa's son Mitsumura OIKAWA lost his territories, ran away and sought refuge in the KASAI clan.

Mitsufusa OIKAWA's great-grandson Mitsumura OIKAWA was killed in the Yuki War, so that the line temporarily went to ruin; Mitsumasa's son Mitsumura OIKAWA lost his territories, ran away and sought refuge in the KASAI clan.

sen.j: 葛西持信は光村に領地を与えて家臣とした（この時、下総に残った一族もかなりいたらしく、千葉県北部に及川氏が集中しており、現在の全及川氏の6％が千葉県人）。
sen.e: Mochinobu KASAI gave territories to Mitsumura and made him his retainer (at that time, many of the families seems to have remained in Shimousa and OIKAWA clan concentrates in the north part of Chiba prefecture and at present 6％ of all OIKAWA clan are residents of Chiba prefecture.

Mochinobu KASAI gave territories to Mitsumura and made him his retainer (at that time, many families seemed to remain in Shimousa; the OIKAWA clan concentrates in the northern part of Chiba Prefecture, and currently six percent of all OIKAWA clan are residents of Chiba Prefecture).

Mochinobu KASAI gave territories to Mitsumura and made him his retainer (at that time, many families seemed to remain in Shimousa; the OIKAWA clan concentrates in the northern part of Chiba Prefecture, and currently six percent of all OIKAWA clan are residents of Chiba Prefecture).

sen.j: 十五世紀中頃（室町時代）、及川定嗣の子孫は葛西家に対して謀叛を起こしたが、光村がこれを鎮圧。
sen.e: In the middle of fifth century (Muromachi period), the offsprings of Sadatsugu OIKAWA raised a rebellion against KASAI clan, but Mitsumura suppressed this.
In the mid-fifth century (the Muromachi period), the offspring of Sadatsugu OIKAWA raised a rebellion against the KASAI clan, but Mitsumura suppressed it.
In the mid-fifteenth century (the Muromachi period), the offspring of Sadatsugu OIKAWA raised a rebellion against the KASAI clan, but Mitsumura suppressed it.

sen.j: それで定嗣の系統は滅亡し、光村の家系が取って代わり、及川氏は多くの分流を派生しつつ、奥州に増え広がった。
sen.e: And thus the Sadatsugu family line was destroyed, instead the Mitsumura family line took over this and OIKAWA clan gave rise to many branches, spread and increased over Oshu.
Thus the Sadatsugu family line was destroyed, whereupon the Mitsumura family line took over; the OIKAWA clan gave rise to many branches, spread and increased throughout Oshu.
Thus the Sadatsugu family line was destroyed, whereupon the Mitsumura family line took over; the OIKAWA clan gave rise to many branches, spread and increased throughout Oshu.

sen.j: 現在、及川という苗字は岩手県の中部南部と宮城県の北部を中心としつつも（両県合わせて全及川氏の53％）、青森・秋田・山形・福島の東北地方各県に散在している。
sen.e: At present the family name OIKAWA centers on the middle and south part of Iwate prefecture and the north part of Miyagi prefecture (53％ of all OIKAWA clan live in both prefectures), but was scattered around Tohoku region prefectures such as Aomori, Akita, Yamagata and Fukushima.

Currently, the OIKAWA family name centers on the middle and southern parts of Iwate Prefecture and the northern part of Miyagi Prefecture (53％ of all OIKAWA clan live in both prefectures), but was scattered around the prefectures of the Tohoku region such as Aomori, Akita, Yamagata and Fukushima.

Currently, the OIKAWA family name centers on the middle and southern parts of Iwate Prefecture and the northern part of Miyagi Prefecture (53％ of all OIKAWA clan live in both prefectures), but was scattered around the prefectures of the Tohoku region such as Aomori, Akita, Yamagata and Fukushima.

sen.j: 十六世紀初頭（戦国時代中頃）、光村の孫・及川重胤は江刺氏と戦って敗れ、光村の家系は衰退した。
sen.e: During the early sixteenth century (the middle of Sengoku period (period of warring states)), Mitsumura's grandson Shigetane OIKAWA fought with Esashi clan and was defeated and the Mitsumura family line went to ruin.

During the early sixteenth century (the mid-Sengoku (Warring States) period), Mitsumura's grandson Shigetane OIKAWA fought with the Esashi clan but was defeated, and consequently the Mitsumura family line went to ruin.

During the early sixteenth century (the mid-Sengoku (Warring States) period), Mitsumura's grandson Shigetane OIKAWA fought with the Esashi clan but was defeated, and consequently the Mitsumura family line went to ruin.

sen.j: 代わって頼只の子孫・及川頼高が城を継承した。
sen.e: Instead, Yoritada's offspring Yoritaka OIKAWA succeeded to the castle.
Instead, Yoritada's offspring Yoritaka OIKAWA succeeded to the castle.
Instead, Yoritada's offspring Yoritaka OIKAWA succeeded to the castle.

sen.j: 滅亡
sen.e: Fall
Fall
Fall

sen.j: 十六世紀中頃（戦国時代末期）、頼高の孫・及川頼家の時、同族間の内紛により主君葛西氏に領地を召し上げられてこの家系も没落し多くは帰農した。
sen.e: During the middle of sixteenth century (late Sengoku period), the time of Yoriie OIKAWA, grandson of Yoritaka, they were deprived of the territory by his master KASAI clan and the family line went to ruin and took up farming again.

During the mid-sixteenth century (the late Sengoku period), in the time of Yoriie OIKAWA, a grandson of Yoritaka, they were deprived of the territory by his master, the KASAI clan; subsequently, the family line went to ruin and took up farming again.

During the mid-sixteenth century (the late Sengoku period), in the time of Yoriie OIKAWA, a grandson of Yoritaka, they were deprived of the territory by his master, the KASAI clan; subsequently, the family line went to ruin and took up farming again.

sen.j: また重胤の家系は衰えながらも及川重氏が葛西家臣として生き残っていたが、のちに豊臣秀吉の時代になり、葛西氏が秀吉に滅ぼされると一族はみな浪人となって、葛西・大崎一揆に加わる者もいた。
sen.e: Shigeuji OIKAWA survived as a retainer of KASAI clan though the Shigetane family line declined, but later during the time of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, KASAI clan was destroyed by Hideyoshi and all the family became ronins (masterless samurai) and some of them joined Kasai-Osaki-ikki (the revolt of the former retainers of the Kasai clan and the Osaki clan).

Shigeuji OIKAWA survived as a retainer of the KASAI clan although the Shigetane family line declined, but later, during the time of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, the KASAI clan was destroyed by Hideyoshi; all the family became ronins (masterless samurai), and some of them joined Kasai-Osaki-ikki (the revolt of the former retainers of the Kasai and Osaki clans).

Shigeuji OIKAWA survived as a retainer of the KASAI clan although the Shigetane family line declined, but later, during the time of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, the KASAI clan was destroyed by Hideyoshi; all the family became ronins (masterless samurai), and some of them joined Kasai-Osaki-ikki (the revolt of the former retainers of the Kasai and Osaki clans).

sen.j: 最後には及川重秀（光村の子孫）や及川信次（頼家の子）のように、伊達氏や南部氏の家臣となるものも出た。
sen.e: Eventually some of them became retainers of DATE clan and NANBU clan like Shigehide OIKAWA (offspring of Mitsumura) or Nobutsugu OIKAWA (son of Yoriie).
Eventually, some of them became retainers of the DATE and NANBU clans, like Shigehide OIKAWA (an offspring of Mitsumura) or Nobutsugu OIKAWA (a son of Yoriie).
Eventually, some of them became retainers of the DATE and NANBU clans, like Shigehide OIKAWA (an offspring of Mitsumura) or Nobutsugu OIKAWA (a son of Yoriie).

sen.j: （現在、及川という苗字は北海道に13％、東京都に7％が住む他、茨城・埼玉・静岡の各県にもいる）。
sen.e: (At present, as for the family name OIKAWA, 13％ of it is in Hokkaido, 7％ in Tokyo prefecture and some of it in Ibaragi prefecture, Saitama prefecture and Shizuoka prefecture.)
(Today, as for the OIKAWA family name, thirteen percent of it is in Hokkaido, seven percent in Tokyo Prefecture and some of it is in the prefectures of Ibaragi, Saitama and Shizuoka).
(Today, as for the OIKAWA family name, thirteen percent of it is in Hokkaido, seven percent in Tokyo and some of it is in the prefectures of Ibaragi, Saitama and Shizuoka).
sen.cmt: Tokyoの後のPrefectureを除去しました。

sen.j: 中世には葛西氏の家臣となって奥州に土着し、三つの家系が交互に興亡して近隣の諸勢力と抗争しつつ、多くの分家庶流を生んで繁茂した。
sen.e: In medieval times they were localized in Oshu as retainers of KASAI clan and the three family lines rose and fell alternately and conflicted with neighboring forces and spawned many branch families.
In medieval times they were localized in Oshu as retainers of the KASAI clan; the three family lines rose and fell alternately, had conflicts with neighboring forces and spawned many branch families.

sen.j: 家により多様な家紋が使われているが、しいていえば片喰（かたばみ）紋系が多い。
sen.e: Various family crests were used depending on the families, but when you come right down to it, there were many Katabami crest (cuckooflower).
Various crests were used depending on the family, but ultimately there were many Katabami (cuckooflower) crests.

tit.j: 及川氏から派生した苗字
tit.e: The family names derived from OIKAWA clan.

sen.j: 及川氏から分派した家には「男沢氏」「鱒淵氏」「鹿折氏」「小野寺氏（源姓小野寺）」等がある。
sen.e: There are branch families from OIKAWA clan such as "OTOKOZAWA clan," "MASUBUCHI clan," "SHISHIORI clan," "ONODERA clan (ONODERA of the MINAMOTO family)" and so on.
